data.title: Bob Hoskins
data.meta_description: Short, tubby, prematurely balding and with a rasping cockney accent, Bob Hoskins was not obvious star material. However, despite being, in his own words, “five foot six and cubed” — or in the words
data.text:
Short, tubby, prematurely balding and with a rasping cockney accent, Bob Hoskins was not obvious star material. However, despite being, in his own words, “five foot six and cubed” — or in the words of one critic “like a testicle on legs” — he had the indefinable presence that lights up a cinema or television screen and enjoyed a successful career, accent notwithstanding, on both sides of the Atlantic.

Playing fast-talking gangsters and tough men with just a hint of vulnerability — in The Long Good Friday, Mona Lisa and Who Framed Roger Rabbit? — he became one of Britain’s biggest Hollywood exports in the Eighties, with scripts piling up on the doormat of his north London home.
